newsitem.title: UK: Stocks fall in Tokyo, post slight gain in London.
newsitem.headline: Stocks fall in Tokyo, post slight gain in London.

text.p: Here is how major stock markets outside the United States ended Tuesday.

LONDON - Shares ended a nervous session mixed as uncertainty over interest rates was offset by another firm morning session on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 index recovered from a near 30-point decline to finish the day 1.5 points higher at 4,195.5.

FRANKFURT - German shares ended bourse trade sharply lower as dealers said nervousness at recent record levels was finally translating into a long-anticipated correction. The DAX-30 index ended down 53.97 points at 2,976.71. In post-bourse trade the index rose 1.47 to 3,000.66.

PARIS - French stocks turned positive during the last half hour of trading and finished higher after U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave an upbeat assessment of the U.S. economy. The blue-chip CAC-40 index finished up 3.78 points at 2,409.88 after recovering from a session low of 2,384.77.
ZURICH - Swiss shares recovered from a dip below 4,000 points in the blue-chip Swiss Market Index (SMI) around midday to end slightly higher as investors concentrated on Sulzer.
Shares in Sulzer soared around 17 percent on plans to sell-off some 25 percent of its Sulzer Medica unit. The Broad Swiss Performance Index (SPI) ended at 2,581.59 points, up 6.92 points.

TOKYO - Tokyo stocks ended in negative territory, unable to recover from Monday's losses of more than 3 percent. Brokers said the market was still disenchanted with the outlook for the economy and the government's economic plans. The Nikkei 225 finished down 122.18 points at 17,358.16.

HONG KONG - Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index broke its record run with a lower close as investors took profits ahead of Fed Chairman Greenspan's testimony to the Senate banking committee. After four straight record closes, the blue-chip index finished down 135.45 points at 13,732.79.

SYDNEY - Australian shares drifted to a lower close on precautionary profit-taking in resource issues ahead of a speech by Greenspan later in the day. The key market barometer, the All Ordinaries index, closed 13.9 points lower at 2,430.3, near its intra-day low of 2,427.9.
JOHANNESBURG - South African industrial shares ended a quiet day weak, knocked down by futures trades. Golds were flat amid a lack of interest due to the ailing bullion price.
The overall index fell 38.7 points to 6,738.7 points, the industrial index shed 63.9 to 8,113.9, points and the gold index was unchanged from Monday's close of 1,419.1.
